Question Text: Another term for POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is _______________.
Choices:
a. Public Available Telephone Network
b. Public Switched Telephone Exchange
c. Phone Switched Transport Network
d. Public Switched Telephone Network
e. Public Available Telephone Exchange
LLM Explanation: POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is another term for the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). The PSTN is the global collection of interconnected voice-oriented public telephone networks, both commercial and government-owned. It's the aggregation of circuit-switching telephone networks that has evolved from the days of Alexander Graham Bell.

Question Text: A baud rate is a measurement of the number of ______________________.
Choices:
a. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
b. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every second
c. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every second
d. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
LLM Explanation: A baud rate measures the number of bits that can be transmitted across a telephone line every second. It represents the signaling rate or symbol rate of a communication channel.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2013). Data Communications and Networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill Education.', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baud']

Question Text: What system did Duke grads build that is still in use today?
Choices:
a. POTS
b. PSTN
c. USENET
d. DSL
LLM Explanation: USENET, a worldwide distributed discussion system, was developed by Duke University graduate students Tom Truscott and Jim Ellis in 1979. It allowed users to read and post messages to newsgroups. While not as widely used today, USENET is still an active communication platform on the Internet. The other choices are unrelated: POTS stands for 'Plain Old Telephone Service', PSTN is the 'Public Switched Telephone Network', and DSL is 'Digital Subscriber Line' technology for Internet access over phone lines.

Question Text: Which device is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection?
Choices:
a. ATM
b. Modem
c. Ethernet cables
d. USENET
LLM Explanation: A modem, short for modulator-demodulator, is a device that converts digital data from a computer into analog signals that can be transmitted over telephone lines and back to digital signals to be read by a computer on the other end. This allows data transfer across dial-up connections.

Question Text: Modems take data that computers can understand and turn them into _____ that can be transmitted over POTS.
Choices:
a. Audible wavelengths
b. Baud rates
c. Modulating electrical charges
d. PSTN
LLM Explanation: Modems convert digital data from computers into audible wavelengths or analog signals that can be transmitted over plain old telephone service (POTS) lines. The modem modulates the digital data into analog audio tones for transmission and demodulates the audio tones back into digital data on the receiving end.

Choices:
a. Transmission 1
b. Transportation 1
c. Transmission System 1
d. Transportation System 1
LLM Explanation: T1 is short for Transmission 1. It refers to a digital transmission system for voice and data communication, standardized to transmit data at 1.544 megabits per second over two twisted pair copper wires or coaxial cable. T1 lines are commonly used to connect networks across remote distances.

Question Text: How fast is a T1 line?
Choices:
a. 128 Mb/sec
b. 1.544 Mb/sec
c. 1 Mb/sec
d. 44.763 Mb/sec
LLM Explanation: A T1 line is a digital transmission link with a capacity of 1.544 megabits per second (Mb/sec). It is a dedicated, point-to-point connection often used by businesses for high-speed data transmission and Internet access.

Question Text: Select all statements that are true of cable internet connections.
Choices:
a. They're wireless connections
b. They're broadband connections
c. They're dial-up connections
d. They're shared bandwidth connections
LLM Explanation: Cable internet connections are broadband connections that provide high-speed internet access using the same coaxial cables that deliver cable television signals. They are not wireless connections, as they require a physical cable connection to the home. Cable internet is also not a dial-up connection, which uses telephone lines and has much slower speeds. Cable internet connections are shared bandwidth connections, meaning that the available bandwidth is shared among multiple users in a neighborhood, which can lead to slower speeds during peak usage times.

Question Text: What are the subprotocols for PPP (Point to Point Protocol)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. FCS
b. LCP
c. Compression
d. NCP
LLM Explanation: The subprotocols for PPP are LCP (Link Control Protocol) and NCP (Network Control Protocol). LCP is responsible for establishing, configuring, and testing the data-link connection, while NCP is used for establishing and configuring different network-layer protocols over PPP. FCS (Frame Check Sequence) is a field in the PPP frame used for error detection, not a subprotocol. Compression can be negotiated as an option during the LCP phase, but it is not a separate subprotocol.

Question Text: What do you call the demarcation point for fiber technologies?
Choices:
a. ONT
b. FTTN
c. FTTX
d. DSLAM
LLM Explanation: The demarcation point for fiber technologies is called an Optical Network Terminal (ONT). The ONT is the device that terminates the fiber optic line from the Internet Service Provider (ISP) and converts it into a usable form for the subscriber, such as Ethernet. It serves as the interface between the ISP's fiber network and the customer's premises.

Choices:
a. Wireless Local Area Network
b. Wireless Area Network
c. Wired Area Network
d. Wide Area Network
LLM Explanation: WAN stands for Wide Area Network. A WAN is a computer network that spans a large geographical area, such as across cities, states, or countries. It is distinct from a LAN (Local Area Network) which covers a smaller area like a home, office, or group of nearby buildings.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2013). Data Communications and Networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill Education.', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-wan-wide-area-network.html']

Question Text: In a WAN, what is the area between a demarcation point and the ISP's core network known as?
Choices:
a. a local loop
b. a Local Area Network
c. A local link
d. An access point
LLM Explanation: In a Wide Area Network (WAN), the area between a demarcation point (the point where the customer's network ends and the service provider's network begins) and the Internet Service Provider's (ISP) core network is known as the local loop. The local loop, also called the 'last mile', is the physical link or circuit that connects the customer's premises to the ISP's nearest point of presence or central office.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a ______________.
Choices:
a. port forwarding VPN
b. one-to-many VPN
c. data link VPN
d. site-to-site VPN
LLM Explanation: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a site-to-site VPN. It connects two specific sites, such as two branch offices of a company, using a virtual private network tunnel. The VPN tunnel encapsulates and encrypts data transmitted between the two sites, creating a secure connection over a public network like the Internet.
URLs: ['NIST Special Publication 800-77 Revision 1, Guide to IPsec VPNs, https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-77r1.pdf', 'Cisco Networking Academy, Connecting Networks v7.0, Module 2: Point-to-Point Connections, https://www.netacad.com/courses/networking/connecting-networks']

Question Text: Who handles sending data from one site to another?
Choices:
a. T-carrier line
b. CTO
c. ISP
d. VPN
LLM Explanation: The Internet Service Provider (ISP) handles sending data from one site to another over the Internet. ISPs provide access to the Internet and the infrastructure to route data packets between different networks. T-carrier lines are digital transmission systems, CTOs are executive roles, and VPNs provide secure remote access, but the ISP is responsible for the actual transmission of data between sites.

Question Text: How many address fields does an 802.11 header contain?
LLM Explanation: The 802.11 header contains 3 address fields. These are used to specify the source address, destination address, and the BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier) which identifies the access point. The fourth address field is optional and used only in ad hoc mode.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']

Choices:
a. a collision domain
b. a point-to-point wireless connection
c. an example of an ad-hoc network
d. Individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network
LLM Explanation: Wireless channels are individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network. They allow multiple devices to communicate simultaneously without interfering with each other by using different frequencies within the allotted spectrum.
URLs: ['CWNA Certified Wireless Network Administrator Study Guide by David D. Coleman and David A. Westcott', '802.11 Wireless Networks: The Definitive Guide by Matthew S. Gast']

Question Text: Which of the following frequencies do wireless networks typically operate on? Select all that apply.
LLM Explanation: Wireless networks typically operate on the 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequency bands. The 2.4GHz band is the most common and widely used due to its compatibility with many devices. The 5GHz band offers higher speeds and less interference but has a shorter range compared to 2.4GHz. The other frequencies mentioned, 1.544GHz and 88MHz, are not typically used for Wi-Fi networks.

Question Text: WPA3 was built with the intention of replacing which protocol?
Choices:
a. WPA2
b. WLAN
c. WEP
d. IEEE 802.11
LLM Explanation: WPA3 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 3) was developed as a replacement for WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2). WPA3 aims to enhance wireless security by introducing new features such as increased cryptographic strength, improved password-based authentication, and better protection against brute-force attacks. While WPA2 has been widely used and provided significant improvements over its predecessor WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy), WPA3 is designed to address the vulnerabilities and security concerns that have emerged over time in WPA2.
URLs: ['Wi-Fi Alliance. (2018). Wi-Fi Alliance® introduces Wi-Fi CERTIFIED WPA3™ security. https://www.wi-fi.org/news-events/newsroom/wi-fi-alliance-introduces-wi-fi-certified-wpa3-security', 'Cisco. (2021). Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3). https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/what-is-wpa3.html']

Question Text: An 802.11 frame contains a number of fields. Which field describes the version of 802.11 that is being used?
Choices:
a. Sequence control
b. Frame control
c. Address
d. Duration
LLM Explanation: The frame control field in an 802.11 frame contains information that defines the type of 802.11 frame and provides information necessary to process the frame. This includes the protocol version, which specifies the version of the 802.11 standard being used.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']
